Hi everyone, I am new to Dungeon World and excited to be apart of the community. Loaded Question: Any tips?
<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/105472060898626050077_photo.jpg'> Matt Horam</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-23 22:42:58 (edited: 2017-02-23 22:42:58)</cite></p>
        <p>Welcome! Have you read the Unofficial Guide? It&#39;s really helpful.<br /><a href="https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3269630/dwdotcom/eon-guide/Dungeon%20World%20Guide%20pdf%20version%201.2.pdf" data-embed="CM8CCAAScGh0dHBzOi8vZGwuZHJvcGJveHVzZXJjb250ZW50LmNvbS91LzMyNjk2MzAvZHdkb3Rjb20vZW9uLWd1aWRlL0R1bmdlb24lMjBXb3JsZCUyMEd1aWRlJTIwcGRmJTIwdmVyc2lvbiUyMDEuMi5wZGY66wEI8f-" data-attachment-render-hint="1" class="ot-anchor">https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3269630/dwdotcom/eon-guide/Dungeon%20World%20Guide%20pdf%20version%201.2.pdf</a></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/101868923979184920256_photo.jpg'> mook abu</h4>

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/118408641603864909644_photo.jpg'> Joshua Faller</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-23 22:45:50 (edited: 2017-02-23 22:45:50)</cite></p>
        <p>The Discern Realities podcast is a pretty great primer. I think listening to actual play helps too. Might want to scrounge up The 16 Hit point Dragon too, it&#39;s a pretty rock solid resource.</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/101126823496630380540_photo.jpg'> Oli Jeffery</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-23 22:49:35 (edited: 2017-02-23 22:49:35)</cite></p>
        <p>Dungeon World plays like you played D&amp;D when you were a kid, back before you&#39;d actually read all the rules and had fun with it, but without fudging anything. Play it in that spirit.</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/100495092599585582455_photo.jpg'> Ray Otus</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-23 23:37:12 (edited: 2017-02-23 23:37:12)</cite></p>
        <p>I second Discern Realities, and I&#39;ll raise you a great article by John Aegard. It is ostensibly about running DW as a one-shot, but it&#39;s great advice for starting a game even if you plan on going for 30 sessions. <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/17ypjtlHfcwqrU_-x4b7o0e8tZ_dN2TiNLUu48MLAw7Y/edit" class="ot-anchor">https://docs.google.com/document/d/17ypjtlHfcwqrU_-x4b7o0e8tZ_dN2TiNLUu48MLAw7Y/edit</a></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/116013665970125878211_photo.jpg'> Yochai Gal</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-24 00:26:57 (edited: 2017-02-24 00:26:57)</cite></p>
        <p>Read the DW book, cover to cover. Then, read it again, but skip around a bunch! Or the other way around.<br /><br />Check out the Dungeon World subreddit, and the dungeonworld channel on <a href="http://rpg-talk.com" class="ot-anchor">rpg-talk.com</a>. Don&#39;t be afraid to ask questions! <br /><a href="http://rpg-talk.com" data-embed="" data-attachment-render-hint="2" class="ot-anchor">rpg-talk.com</a></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/105472060898626050077_photo.jpg'> Matt Horam</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-24 01:03:19 (edited: 2017-02-24 01:03:19)</cite></p>
        <p>They&#39;re just good resources (like the Tavern) if you get stuck. Don&#39;t feel overwhelmed, it&#39;s such a simple system at its core that you could explain it in an infographic or two, really.</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/118088719859349999400_photo.jpg'> Mark Tygart</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-24 01:07:30 (edited: 2017-02-24 01:07:30)</cite></p>
        <p><a href="http://dieheart.net/useful-stuff/dw-resources/" data-embed="-gsZMjAxNS0wNS0xNVQwOTozMjoyMiswMDowMPoRLmh0dHA6Ly9kaWVoZWFydC5uZXQvdXNlZnVsLXN0dWZmL2R3LXJlc291cmNlcy8" data-attachment-render-hint="1" class="ot-anchor">http://dieheart.net/useful-stuff/dw-resources/</a></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/105487846931822189120_photo.jpg'> Robert Doe</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-24 01:21:12 (edited: 2017-02-24 01:21:12)</cite></p>
        <p>Like <span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/105472060898626050077" oid="105472060898626050077">Matt Horam</a></span>​ and <span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/101126823496630380540" oid="101126823496630380540">Oli Jeffery</a></span>​ said. Its very simple,  realy it is. 2d6+ appropriate Mod when you attempt something risky and wouldn&#39;t &quot;just happen anyways&quot;. Then, if the result is 9 or less, you the GM get to do something. We call those &quot;things&quot; <b>Moves</b>. Thats all thats to it. Pretty simple</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/105487846931822189120_photo.jpg'> Robert Doe</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-24 01:23:54 (edited: 2017-02-24 01:23:54)</cite></p>
        <p>Oh, and the scariest chapter in the book is <b>Fronts</b>. Let me just ease your worries before they happen and say, Fronts are just &quot;Time Counters&quot;. Just a way to count down bad events. You can use what ever methods you like</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/102595580176380683252_photo.jpg'> Jeremy Strandberg</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-02-24 04:37:19 (edited: 2017-02-24 04:37:19)</cite></p>
        <p>Don&#39;t even bother reading the fronts chapter until after your first session. <br /><br />Play with people you like just hanging out with, especially if they&#39;re clever and creative and quick witted. <br /><br />Show up with some ideas, maybe a specific place to <i>be</i>, but not the why or the when or the who. Ask them: why are you here, what are you after, who else wants it, what happens if you don&#39;t get it first?<br /><br />It&#39;s totally cool if someone wants to use a move, just ask them what that looks like. &quot;Can I hack and slash?&quot; &quot;Yeah, sure but what does that <i>look like</i>?&quot;  &quot;I Defend!&quot; &quot;Cool! How do you <i>do that</i>?&quot;<br /><br />You should almost never ask them to make a move. Say what happens, or is about to happen, and ask what they do. If they do something that you think triggers a move, be like &quot;sounds like you&#39;re defying danger with Dex, yeah?&quot; and have them roll it if they agree. <br /><br />Remember that it&#39;s a conversation and not a board game. Don&#39;t be a stickler for taking turns, but <i>take turns</i>. Like, don&#39;t be rude and don&#39;t let other people be rude. &quot;Hold on their, Fighter, lets see what Cleric is up to...&quot;<br /><br />When they look at you expectantly, it&#39;s your turn to make a move. Make one! Even if it&#39;s just &quot;give them an opportunity&quot; or &quot;tell the requirements/consequences and ask&quot;. <br /><br />Have fun!<br /></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13zgpbpxqfoshlob04cdl54nzjyd3fyzz40k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/102595580176380683252_photo.jpg'> Jeremy Strandberg</h4>

</div>
